Def.Name: Canada Plum
Def.Description: Deciduous shrub or small tree growing up to 33' tall with a trunk up to 10" in diameter, with a low-branched, dense crown of stiff, rigid, branches.
Def.Leaves: Alternate, simple, oblong-ovate or obovate, 2" - 4 1/2" long and 1 3/16" - 2 3/4" wide, wedge-shaped or slightly heart-shaped or rounded at base, slightly tinged with red, are smooth, becoming bright green above and paler beneath when full grown. The leaf petioles are stout, bearing two large dark glands that are usually missing on American plum.
Def.Twigs: Green to black with dark brown or gray buds.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Oblong-oval drupe, 1" - 1 3/16" long with a tough, thick, orange red skin, free from bloom, yellow flesh adherent to the seed; the seed oval, compressed. It matures in late summer or early autumn.
Def.Bark: Gray-brown, older layers coming off in thick plates.
Def.Range: Native to eastern North America from New Brunswick west to southeastern Manitoba, and south to Connecticut across to Iowa.
Def.Remarks: It can easily be confused with the related American plum, differing most obviously in the leaf margins having blunt, gland-tipped teeth, rather than the sharp, glandless teeth of the American plum leaves.
